member.name: P:JetBrains.Application.ICommandLine.NonKeyedParameters
member.summary: Strings that do not start with “/” and do not belong to the previous string with a “/”.

summary.para: Gets the string to be passed on the command line to this host so that the command line of this product would have the key named defined.

If this product is not the default product of the host, the product name will be added to the short key name (to distinguish between keys addressed to different products). The environment (for example, Visual Studio non-default hive) might also add decorations to the key name.

For example, let's consider a key with short name of “SelfDestruction” that belongs to the product named “Kalabash”, currently running in a non-default Visual Studio hive with root suffix “Exp”. This method is given the short key name “Kalabash”, and yields the full ready-for-VS-command-line “Kalabash.SelfDestruction.Exp” key name.
In non-VS or VS default hive, there is no root suffix. If the product is also the default product of the host (not applicable to VS), the resulting full name will just be the short key name.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Application.Configuration.ISaveSettings
member.summary: An interface for a component that has some settings and they should be saved whenever all of the application settings are being saved. // TODO: rework when we have a mature settings model.

summary.para: Tells the component container to reload the settings from the persistent media, deserialize them from the bag, and apply them to the components.
If a particular component has not been initialized yet, it will be called for / before its . Otherwise, those xml-related methods will be called on it for the second and so on time.
Tells the component container that it's about time to query the components of their settings, serialize them to the bag, and write that to the persistent media.
You must make sure this method is called on component containers in the end of the session. The component container will never save settings on its own.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Application.Configuration.IXmlExternalizable
member.summary: An interface for components that support serializing their settings into the XML settings file.

summary.para: This method is called on the component to populate it with default or loaded settings, unless the component implements and returns True from its handler.
The element is taken from the settings file, if available.
If not, and there are settings files from the older versions, and the component does not implement , this method is called with the old settings.
Otherwise, this method is called with an empty element or a Null value.
For the first time, this method is called right before component's init.
The settings-reading protocol might be executed more than once thru the component lifetime.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Application.IHostCommandLine
member.summary: Command line of the host, which includes both product-shared keys and all keys that belong to each product. In VS, created over the VS command line object. In standalone, created over a string array.

summary.para: Gets the string to be passed on the command line to this host so that the product-specific command lines would get for parsing.
For calling from s to serve their requests.

For example, let's consider a non-default Visual Studio hive with root suffix “Exp”, a key with short name of “SelfDestruction”, for the product named “Kalabash”. This method is given the product-decorated “Kalabash.SelfDestruction” key name (formed from the short name by some ), and yields the full ready-for-VS-command-line “Kalabash.SelfDestruction.Exp” key name.
In non-VS or VS default hive, returns the original string. If the product is also the default product of the host (not applicable to VS), the resulting full name will just be the short key name.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Application.ProductCommandLine.#ctor(JetBrains.Application.IHostCommandLine,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Init.
member.param: Host command line to filter and strip key names.

Prefix of the product (dot not included). Keys with this prefix (followed by a dot) are attributed to the current product and given out. Case-sensitivity flags of the command line request also applies to the prefix.
If the host has a default product, then keys without prefix are also attributed to that product. An example is a standalone application (eg DotTrace).

member.summary: Describes the product. The instances are spawned by the shell and populated with the assembly configuration and product edition parameters.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Application.IApplicationDescriptor
member.summary:
For a JetBrains .NET Platform based product, describes the static properties for that product. Being static, an Application Descriptor can be created without a Shell. It's used for getting static product info without a running product, eg for packing the assemblies for the setup package, or harvesting entities like registration attributes from all of the product assemblies. The AD can tell product properties, like name, version, build date, and URIs, and the list of product assemblies for various product configurations. A configuration is defined elsewhere, when starting the Shell over this AD, or specified for the setup package builder to tell which DLLs should go into setup. To start a Shell, create an AD of the specific type, give it enough context as needed, and call its overload of StartShell. A Shell cannot be created directly. A newly-created Shell remembers its underlying AD and uses it to get the list of the assemblies to run for the product. Even though you can create an AD directly, things Visual Studio integration package and setup package builder use autodiscovery to locate the AD because they're not product-specific and cannot know the exact AD class type. An defnies the Application Descriptor to be created.
Note: is all-static and the same throughout all the product runs, is bound to the single product run (but multiple shell runs, if needed), so it binds to cmdline and VS version, and the is for a single Shell run (in Visual Studio, our Shell can be started and stopped multiple times within the same VS run), and its is unique per run.

summary.para: Gets whether the installer is currently running in the VS-version-neutral mode.
The installer is conscequently run on the same data for each of VS versions supported, to produce VS-version-specific data for each VS.
Also it's run once in VS-version-neutral mode to collect the shared things (and avoid collecting them more than once, if included in version-specific runs).
When False, you can use the , , and attributes to learn the version. When True, the abovementioned properties cannot be access, and will throw.

summary.para: Starts the progress to run through the [0..totalWorkUnits] range. You MUST call at the end. Use to move the progress across the range.
Generally, you SHOULD set the to identify the current execution span, once per -, and change the when doing to comment on the progress.

If you would like to delegate a sub-range to a nested routine, you SHOULD create a and pass the resulting to the routine, so that it ran a whole range from its point of view, which would then map to a sub-range of this progress indicator.

member.param: Progress indicator.
The inclusive upper limit of the progress range.
The value to be set for the run. You SHOULD NOT leave it unmodified, unless you are running a subprogress.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Application.Progress.ITaskExecutor.ExecuteTask(System.String,JetBrains.Application.Progress.TaskCancelable,System.Action{JetBrains.Application.Progress.IProgressIndicator})
member.summary: Executes the task without exiting the method until the task is completed.

param.name: name
param.para: This is used for the progress window title by the UI progress indicators.
The long form of the task caption should go to the of the 's .
Prepended with the product name automatically. Might be empty, in which case the product name will be used.

member.param: The task to execute.

param.name: cancelable
param.para: Whether the task could be canceled by the user, if the task progress indication provided by supports canceling.

The pattern is supported, which means that an is plugged on the task thread to throw a when called for a check with a False; such an exception is called by the task executor and converted into a False return value.

member.returns: Whether the task has completed execution (i.e. was not canceled). Note that even a task could be canceled by setting to False or throwing a or letting some other exception out of the task function.
member.remarks: If you would like to return any values from the , assign them to local variables within the closure.

summary.para: A product edition has two representations: (1) a that's basically a string identifier that is used for the license information and user display, and (2) a set of assembly configurations that comprise the given edition.
This function converts between these representations.

member.param: The list of assembly configurations to be parsed as a product edition.

Whether other assembly configurations not controlled by the product edition are allowed in the collection. This is the case when the configuration of a running Shell is passed in, because it also might include public/internal, VS version and other configurations.
Called when an error is encountered. Throw the exception to have a never-returning-Null function, or pass in to handle failures softly.
member.returns: Product edition on success, a in case of a failure or for a product that does not support product editions.

summary.para: Establishes a data flow between two properties. The assignment to the target property only happens in the guarded context on the primary thread.
It is guaranteed that the values are properly serialized, ie a delayed early value will not overwrite a later direct execution.
Returns a cookie for terminating the flow.
Not suitable for high-throughput property changes, as it schedulles a new guarded execution for each change. Use in such cases.
Establishes a data flow between two collections. The changes to the target collection only happen in the guarded context on the primary thread.
It is guaranteed that the values are properly serialized, ie a delayed early value will not overwrite a later direct execution.
Returns a cookie for terminating the flow.
Not suitable for high-throughput changes, as it schedulles a new guarded execution for each change.
Uses the given callback merger for guarding the changes.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Application.ExceptionReport.ExceptionData.HeaderText
member.summary: Additional text in the header, just before the full stack traces of the exception. Might contain environmental info, build description, etc. Most of the technical data must be added to the exception data itself, with inside your implementation of . It will appear in the detailed stack traces among the data field of the outermost exception. If you'd like your data get into the header text, call inside your implementation of . Use sparingly.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Application.ExecuteOrQueueSingular
member.summary: Wraps by executing the same single action. If the execution has been delayed because another execution is in progress ( scenario), does not queue any more executions until the pending one is executed. When the object is disposed of, drops all of the pending executions so that they're never executed after the . Mostly like a , but without any grouping or additional delaying.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Application.IShellLocks.AcquireReadLock
member.summary: Fetches read lock - the lock which is used to control read-access to ReSharper data (such as PSI, documents, etc.) and is obtained by threads that perform read-operations.
member.remarks:
Read lock cannot be acquired when the write lock is acquired by another thread and execution will be blocked until the write lock is released. You do not need to acquire read lock in the UI thread (since write operations cannot be performed in any thread different from the UI thread).
Use method to release read lock.
NOTE: the best way to hold read lock for a block of code is to use

member.name: M:JetBrains.Application.IShellLocks.AcquireWriteLock
member.summary: Fetches write lock - the lock which is used to control write-access to ReSharper data (such as PSI, documents, etc.) and is obtained by threads that perform write-operations.
member.remarks:
Write lock cannot be acquired when the read lock is acquired by another thread and execution will be blocked until the read lock is released. Acquiring of the write lock is allowed only in the UI thread (and so you cannot perform any write operations from non-UI thread). Note that you do not have to obtain the write lock explicitly in most of cases. All low-level write methods (such as PSI or document modifications) obtain write lock automatically. You may need to obtain write lock if your subsystem (similar to PSI or documents) has its own data to be modified in write operations only.
Use method to release write lock.
NOTE: the best way to hold write lock for a block of code is to use

member.name: M:JetBrains.Application.IShellLocks.GrantWriteAccess(System.Threading.Thread)
member.summary: Grants write access rights to the specified secondary thread. This function can only be called from the primary UI thread. The typical situation in which it can be useful is when a time-consuming write operation needs to be performed. It is supposed that during this operation the UI thread is blocked (by e.g. a modal window). Only one thread can be granted write access at time.
member.param: Thread to grant write access to

member.name: M:JetBrains.Application.IShellLocksEx.ExecuteOrQueueReadLock(JetBrains.Application.IShellLocks,System.String,System.Action)

summary.para: Executes an action on the primary thread in a guarded context.
If called on a foreign thread, executes the action asynchronously, like .

If called on the guarded thread, checks for reentrancy. If there are no guarded executions on the stack yet, executes the action immediately and synchronously. Otherwise, postpones the action for asynchronous execution, like does.
Takes a read lock.

member.param: The name for the task.
The action to execute. Exceptions will be trapped.
member.returns: True if executed immediately, False if queued (-compatible behavior).

member.name: M:JetBrains.Threading.IThreadingEx.CreateGroupingEvent(JetBrains.Threading.IThreading,JetBrains.DataFlow.Lifetime,System.String,System.TimeSpan,System.Action)

summary.para: Creates and registers an event that groups multiple incoming signals within a time span and issues only one outgoing signal for them.
This allows to accomodate for external events firing at a high rate and execute the handler only when their activity suspends.
The object is thread-safe: the incoming event may fire on any thread, the outgoing activity always happens on the primary thread in a guarded context.
This function is free-threaded.

member.param: Limiting lifetime. If the lifetime ends before the action is executed, the execution is canceled.
A name to identify the event.
The grouping interval. The incoming events are grouped until there's a pause of the length, and after that the outgoing event is fired. The interval must be not above .
Optional. The action for the outgoing event. This action will be executed on the primaty thread and under the . If you omit this action, advise the event on the return value.
member.returns: The event on which the incoming events can be fired. Must be disposed of.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Threading.IThreadingEx.QueueRecurring(JetBrains.Threading.IThreading,System.String,System.TimeSpan,System.Action)

summary.para: Queues the action to execute asynchronously on the primary thread in a guarded context at recurring intervals. Can be used on the primary thread only.
Returns a token that cancels the recurring action execution. This token must be eventually disposed of.
When the application gets inactive, the action is executed once, and then suspends until the application gets activated again.
A is preventing reentrancy between the actions.

member.param: The name for the task.
The action to execute. Exceptions will be trapped.
A non-negative time interval.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Threading.IThreadingEx.QueueRecurring(JetBrains.Threading.IThreading,JetBrains.DataFlow.Lifetime,System.String,System.TimeSpan,System.Action)

Returns a token that cancels the recurring action execution. This token must be eventually disposed of.
When the application gets inactive, the action is executed once, and then suspends until the application gets activated again.
A is preventing reentrancy between the actions.

member.param: Limiting lifetime. If the lifetime ends before the action is executed, the execution is canceled.
The name for the task.
The action to execute. Exceptions will be trapped.
A non-negative time interval.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Application.Defines
member.summary: Pre-compile-time defined constants that emulate the C++ #define that has a value.
member.remarks: The set of #defines and their default values are given in an MSBuild file. The defauls could be overridden on the build server.

summary.para: Short company name.
The date when the product was founded. Used for the lower copyright year and so on.
Upgrade Code for the Installation Center family setups. In use starting with Platform-4.

Whether call stacks should be annotated when calling standard object methods. If there's a graph of standard objects identifyable only by names (eg IProperty, ICollection, ISignal, etc), a callstack of their interaction does not give out the names of the entities, unless this option is turned on. Has a perf impact.
Default is ON. OFF for production builds.
Whether debug asserts should be active and throw runtime exceptions.
Default is ON. OFF for production builds.
Whether statistics should be collected by the Statistics class.
Default is OFF.
Whether PDBs for product binaries should be packed into the Setup.
If True, it is an error if a PDB is missing.
Whether XmlDocs for product binaries should be packed into the Setup.
If True, it is an error if an XmlDoc file is missing.
Whether product binaries packed into MSI must have strong names. If True, Setup build will fail unless assemblies have strong names.
Defines whether this is the Production Build — that is, production license should be used instead of the EAP license, and any optional checks should be deactivated.
Demo Define.

A license GUID identifying the product family of the license. Now as we're using version numbers in the license (unlike early versions of ReSharper), this should be persisted throughout the product lifetime.
The license state written to the Registry by the installer, which provides for a free trial.
An identifier for the evaluation license. Change it to reset the evaluation period.
Note: do not change LicenseSupportIdentifier here, edit the property on TeamCity instead.
Name of the IsModeAssert-induced conditional compilation symbol.
Name of the IsModeAssert-induced conditional compilation symbol.
Name of the IsModeAssert-induced conditional compilation symbol.

The minimum .NET Framework version (Build component) required for installing & runnning this product. The platform default is the minimum version required by the platform itself. Usually it's the same for the product.

The minimum .NET Framework version (Major component) required for installing & runnning this product. The platform default is the minimum version required by the platform itself. Usually it's the same for the product.

The minimum .NET Framework version (Minor component) required for installing & runnning this product. The platform default is the minimum version required by the platform itself. Usually it's the same for the product.

The minimum .NET Framework version (Revision component) required for installing & runnning this product. The platform default is the minimum version required by the platform itself. Usually it's the same for the product.
Application version for the licensing subsystem. Usually changes along with the ProductVersionMajor, but has its own numbering plan.
Number of days after installation and before feedback of whatever kind is requested.
Free trial days for a newly-installed product.
Number of days before license expires to notify the user of that.
The product will be inoperational when this time since build date expires. 0 means never expire (release mode), which is the default.
CPU platform of the NUnit runner process. Tests will be executed in this environment. Values: x86, x64, ANY.
Allows running NUnit in parallel (one process per assembly, max CPU-count processes total).
CLR version of the NUnit runner process. Tests will be executed in this environment. Values: v1.1, v2.0, v4.0, ANY.
Version of the NUnit runner used on TeamCity server. The special ReSharper make does better formatting of exception stack traces (without reversing the stacks).
Pragma Once.
Pragma Once.

This full name is actually displayed in the User Interface in the About Boxes and such. It should include the short product name and the marketing version of the product. The bugfix upgate versions are visible thru this field only (eg “ProductName + " 3.0.2"”) and do not get into the actual technical file versions. Those can be found in the ProductInformation file linked into each of the projects.
You MUST NOT use this define where an Application Descriptor is available (this includes any time when Shell is running). This is ONLY for out-of-shell and build-time uses.
Name of the current product. If there're multiple products built on these sources, their least common generic name.
The short ID-like product name, without any version suffixes.
You MUST NOT use this define where an Application Descriptor is available (this includes any time when Shell is running). This is ONLY for out-of-shell and build-time uses.
Main historical Upgrade Code for the R# product line. In 3.0 era, was used by the VS80 branch only. Not used by the new products.
Used by Installation Centers for detecting pre-Platform-4 products in VS80.
Empty by default. Not a GUID type just to allow empty string values.

Side Upgrade Code for the R# products. Was in use in the 3.0 era only, was used by the VS90 branch that had an upgrade line separate from that of VS80. Should be checked for when detecting older versions.
Used by Installation Centers for detecting pre-Platform-4 products in VS90.
Empty by default. Not a GUID type just to allow empty string values.
Same as other ProductUpgradeCodeLegacy, but empty in all the products. Introduced for safe looping thru VS versions. Not a GUID type just to allow empty string values.
Source code control revision string, if available. For a single SVN root, should be the revision number; for complicated cases — a freehand string exposing the source code control state.
URI of the Webpage where the user could buy the product.
URI of the company Website.
URI of the Webpage where the user can download an evaluation version of the product.
Main product webpage URI. Also used for ARPURLINFOABOUT in the installer.
URI to the product community (support/discussion) newsgroups.
URI to Product Help. Used for Online F1 in the product and ARPHELPLINK in the installer.
Email to request for product support. The default is suitable for all JetBrains products.
An URI to submit the Uninstall Feedback from the installer.
This URI has query string parameters that are defined in the installer itself (one of its CAs).
Installer's ARPURLUPDATEINFO. Default is applicable for dotnet products.
URI to get the XSLT with updates info from (see UpdatesManager).

This full name is actually displayed in the User Interface in the About Boxes and such. It should include the short product name and the marketing version of the product. The bugfix upgate versions are visible thru this field only (eg “ProductName + " 3.0.2"”) and do not get into the actual technical file versions. Those can be found in the ProductInformation file linked into each of the projects.
